thread.title: Economists focused on capex data

title: Economists focused on capex data
text:
Sat, Aug 29, 2015, 10:26 AM AEST - Australia Markets closed Economists focused on capex data AAP – 16 minutes ago Print 
With economic growth figures and the RBA's interest rate decision due within a week, the quarterly survey of business investment plans came into sharp focus for economists this week. 
The survey from the Australian Bureau of Statistics (ABS) offers the most comprehensive looks at the economy's medium-term outlook. 
But it's notoriously hard to interpret, because the projections have to be adjusted to allow for a systematic bias, with final outcomes typically well above the early projections. 
But the ratio of outcomes to earlier projections - the so-called realisation ratio - varies from year to year. 
Adjusting the early projections by the previous year's ratio, or the average ration for the preceding five, 10 or 20 years, will produce different adjusted projections. 
HSBC's economists, Paul Bloxham and Daniel Smith, said the projections looked much that same as they did three months ago, with mining capital expenditure (capex) to fall 38 per cent in 2015/16, with non-mining capex to drop eight per cent. 
"But remember, the Capex survey does not cover much of the services sector, where most of the recent jobs growth has been, so the survey may understate the extent to which growth is rebalancing to the non-mining sectors," they said. 
The HSBC team prefers to use the average realisation ratio for the preceding five years to adjust the raw projections, but even then their preference for adjusting the capex projections for each individual sector then adding them up produces a different, and sightly less downbeat, bottom line than adjustment of the projections in aggregate would. 
There is more than one way to skin a cat, a point noted by Andrew Ticehurst at Nomura. 
"This survey always triggers debate in how to translate these expectations into actual or likely outcomes," he said. 
"Our preferred method is to rely on one year 'realisation ratios' (given the current stage of the macro cycle) and a literal interpretation still suggests that total capex could record a double-digit decline in 2015-16, though a slightly less weak result than suggested three months ago." 
And he warned that caution warranted, given that the capex survey only captures about a half of non-mining part of the private business sector. 
Using a one-year realisation ratio - in other words, assuming last year's pattern is repeated this year - still suggest a fall of more than 20 per cent in total capex between 2014/15 and 2015/16. 
That accords with the picture painted by HSBC's slightly different method. 
And differences between economists were not so much about whether the outlook is weak, but exactly how weak it is. 
But, for Westpac's Andrew Hanlan, that's the appropriate word. 
"The key takeout is that capex plans for 2015/16 remain particularly weak, albeit marginally less so than three months ago," Westpac's Andrew Hanlan said. 
"Mining plans are for a sharp cut in capex spending and the service sectors are also looking to reduce investment."   RBA unlikely to change rate stance AAP
